Ransomware.ROLLCOAST: The Rollcoast ransomware, first observed in use by UNC2190 in July 2020, is a dynamic link library (DLL) that encrypts files on logical drives attached to a system. The ransomware has various features allowing it to evade detection: For instance, it has only one ordinal export, which researchers believe could mean the sample was designed to sidestep detection and be invoked within memory, potentially through the Beacon malware provided to affiliates. The Rollcoast ransomware would also check the system language and exit if it detected a non-supported language code (from Russia, Turkey or Albania, for instance). Files are encrypted and renamed to this format: .[]..  Ransomware used by Sabbath, an old threat actor group rebranded. https://www.mandiant.com/resources/sabbath-ransomware-affiliate
Ransomware.ThiefLock: ThiefLock is a Ransomware-as-a-Service that encrypts user data. The affiliates of this RaaS use a variety of legitimate and open-source tools in its campaign to distribute the ransomware. This has included the use of PowerShell to download a backdoor called BazarLoader for assisting with initial reconnaissance and the subsequent delivery of a legitimate remote access tool called ConnectWise. Thieflock affiliate also use a PowerShell script called KeeThief to copy the master key from the KeePass open-source password manager and other tools to capture data and screen shots from compromised systems.  Thieflock affiliate appears to have now switched to the rival Yanluowang ransomware strain https://www.darkreading.com/attacks-breaches/new-ransomware-variant- could-become-next-big-threat
Ransomware.BlackCat: The BlackCat ransomware operation, aka ALPHV, launched in Nov 2021, was claimed to be the most sophisticated ransomware of the year, with a highly-customizable feature set allowing for attacks on a wide range of corporate environments. The ransomware executable is written in Rust, a high-performance and memory-safe language. The ransomware is named by the developers as ALPHV and got promoted on Russian-speaking hacking forums. In return for decrypting the encrypted files, affiliates earn varying revenue shares based on the size of a ransom payment. For example, for ransom payments up to $1.5 million, the affiliate earns 80%, 85% for up to $3 million, and 90% of payments over $3 million, if victims pay in bitcoin there is an additional 15% fee added to the ransom. When encrypting a device, the ransomware uses a random name extension, which is appended to all files and included in the ransom note. Ransom notes are named in the format RECOVER-[extension]-FILES. txt.  This year’s most sophisticated Ransomware https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/alphv-blackcat-this-years- most-sophisticated-ransomware/
Ransomware.BlackSun: This crypto-ransomware encrypts user data with AES + RSA and then demands a ransom of 10.000 Euros in Monero cryptocurrency in order to get the files back. It can spread by hacking through unprotected RDP configurations, email spam and malicious attachments, spoofing downloads, botnets, exploits, malicious ads, web injections, fake updates, repackaged and infected installers. It renames encrypted files by appending the “.BlackSun” extension.
Ransomware.Doitman: This crypto-ransomware encrypts user data using a combination of AES + RSA algorithms and then demands a # BTC ransom to get the files back. Doitman was active in early December 2021. It is targeted at English-speaking users and can spread all over the world. No extension is added to encrypted files, but the file is renamed with a set of numbers and letters in upper case. An example of an encrypted file: 7663726564697374323031305F7836342E6C6F672E68746D6C.  Active threat, added in KB https://id-ransomware.blogspot.com/2021/12/doitman-ransomware.html
Ransomware.Khonsari: Khonsari ransomware makes use of the .NET framework and is written in C#. It weighs in at only 12 KB and contains only the most basic functionality required to perform its ransomware objective. Its size and simplicity is also a strength however - the malware isn’t detected by the system’s built-in Antivirus. Soon after execution, the malware enumerates all mounted drives (apart from C:\) and begins to encrypt all contents found on them. Encryption of the C:\ drive is more targeted, with the ransomware only encrypting user directories, such as Documents, Videos, Pictures, Downloads, and Desktop. Each file is encrypted using the AES 128 CBC algorithm and the extension .khonsari is added.  | Khonsari Novel Khonsari Ransomware Deployed by the Log4Shell Vulnerability https://www.cadosecurity.com/analysis-of-novel-khonsari-ransomware- deployed-by-the-log4shell-vulnerability/
Ransomware.Sfile: Sfile is a malicious program that is classified as ransomware. It is designed to encrypt data, change filenames, and demand payment for decryption. When Sfile malware encrypts, all affected files are appended with the “.BRN-qfp7mkc” extension. The ransom-demand message (“readme_to BRN.inf”) informs victims that their network has been infiltrated and stored files were encrypted.  Old threat, added in the KB. https://www.pcrisk.com/removal-guides/19455-sfile-ransomware

Malware.SpyAgent: SpyAgent dropper is distributed via bogus cryptocurrency-related websites, most of which are in the Russian language. The dropper is equipped with a fake cryptocurrency wallet, surfing plug-ins, or miner. After getting installed on a device, SpyAgent malware downloads other malware having extensive capabilities, including stealing sensitive data. SpyAgent downloads additional stealers such as: AZOrult, RedLine, Cypress and Ducky. Further, it downloads Clipper, a clipboard replacer that replaces different cryptocurrency addresses with attacker-controlled addresses.  Campaign Abusing Legitimate Remote Administrator Tools Uses Fake Cryptocurrency Websites https://www.trendmicro.com/en_no/research/21/k/campaign-abusing-rats-uses- fake-websites.html
Malware.Chinotto: Chinotto is a backdoor that targets both Windows and Android users. Chinotto allows hacking groups to control compromised devices, spy on their users via screenshots, deploy additional payloads, harvest data of interest, and upload it to attacker- controlled servers. The malware allows the actor to target victims with a probable spear-phishing attack for Windows systems and smishing for Android systems. The actor can leverage Windows executable versions and PowerShell versions to control Windows systems, If a victim’s host and mobile are infected at the same time, the malware operator is able to overcome two-factor authentication by stealing SMS messages from the mobile phone. This malware is used by APT37 in their campaigns.  | Details on Chinotto. APT37 targets journalists with Chinotto multi-platform malware https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/apt37-targets-journalists- with-chinotto-multi-platform-malware/
Malware.Ducky: Information stealers like Ducky are malicious programs that are designed to gather sensitive information from a system. In most cases, info stealers target data such as login credentials (like usernames, email addresses, passwords), credit card details (like cardholder name, expiry date, CVV code), and other information from web browsers, instant messengers, email, VPN and other clients.  Campaign Abusing Legitimate Remote Administrator Tools Uses Fake Cryptocurrency Websites https://www.trendmicro.com/en_no/research/21/k/campaign-abusing-rats-uses- fake-websites.html
Malware.Cypress: Cypress is the name of an information stealer that targets quite a wide range of data, it is advertised as the most powerful stealer for its price. It is known that Cypress malware costs $100 and it is for sale on hacker forums. Its developers have written this stealer using the C computer programming language. Once installed, Cypress stores its data in RAM and does not write anything to the hard drive which makes it hardly traceable. Cypress can collect data from all Chromium-based browsers, it can gather login credentials (usernames, email addresses, passwords), credit card details, autofill data, browsing, and download history. Moreover, Cypress can collect data from Mozilla Firefox, Microsoft Edge, Internet Explorer browsers, Microsoft Outlook and Mozilla Thunderbird email clients, session data from Telegram, ProtonVPN, NordVPN, FileZilla clients.  Campaign Abusing Legitimate Remote Administrator Tools Uses Fake Cryptocurrency Websites https://www.trendmicro.com/en_no/research/21/k/campaign-abusing-rats-uses- fake-websites.html
Malware.KeeThief: KeeThief is a PowerShell script. It allows the extraction of KeePass 2.X key material from memory, as well as the backdooring and enumeration of the KeePass trigger system. It is used by threat actors to copy the masterkey from KeePass open- source password manager and other tools to capture data and screenshots from compromised systems.  Malware used by Yanlouwang Ransomware affiliates. https://www.darkreading.com/attacks-breaches/new-ransomware-variant- could-become-next-big-threat
Malware.RouteX: RouteX, a malware that targets Netgear routers. RouteX is designed to turn an infected router into a Socket Secure (SOCKS) proxy that in turn, limits access of the device to the attacker. RouteX also allows an attacker to conduct credential stuffing. After setting a SOCKS proxy, it adds Linux firewall rules to prevent other malware from exploiting the same vulnerability and restrict access to the router to certain IP addresses most likely controlled by the attackers.
Malware.DvrHelper: DvrHelper is a malware infecting IoT devices, targeting port 80. A newer version of Mirai, DvrHelper also learned from its predecessor. To match the increase in security, DvrHelper has eight more DDoS attack modules. It is also the first malware designed to bypass an anti-DDoS solution. Specifically, DvrHelper has two methods that can bypass DDoS defense from one particular content delivery network that also provides DDoS prevention services. The first method targets anti-bot techniques and takes advantage of the challenge-response policies of the provider and the second method uses a shared “Google reCAPTCHA response” token.  Active threat, included in KB https://www.trendmicro.com/vinfo/us/security/news/internet-of-things/routex- malware-found-exploiting-remote-access-vulnerability-in-netgear-routers
Malware.TheMoon: TheMoon is the oldest malware targeting IoT devices. The family was first discovered by SANS ICS in 2014 and it continues to upgrade attack methods and target new vulnerabilities. When the infection is done, iptables rules are imported to the infected device. Through these rules, a wall is built by TheMoon to prevent other malware from infecting the device. The rules are different from each binary. Its target ports include TCP/22 (SSH Remote Login Protocol), TCP/23 (Telnet), TCP/80 (HTTP), TCP/443 (HTTP over SSL/TLS), TCP/7547 (CPE WAN Management Protocol), TCP/8080 (alternative port for HTTP) and UDP/9999 (ASUS Router Infosvr). Each port is mapped to a specific device and vulnerability, with the main target being IP cameras. When the infection is done, the installation script will be replaced with a string “ne kemi mbaruar!” which is “We’re done!” in Albanian.
Malware.Anatsa: Anatsa is a password-stealing Android banking trojan hidden in apps on Google Play Store. It is a rather advanced Android banking trojan with RAT and semi-ATS capabilities. It can also perform classic overlay attacks in order to steal credentials, accessibility logging (capturing everything shown on the user’s screen), and keylogging. Upon the start of installation from Google Play, the user is forced to update the app in order to continue using the app. At this moment, Anatsa payload is downloaded from the C2 server(s), and installed on the device of the unsuspecting victim.  Active threat, included in KB https://www.trendmicro.com/vinfo/us/security/news/internet-of-things/routex- malware-found-exploiting-remote-access-vulnerability-in-netgear- 300,000 Android users impacted by malware apps on Play Store. https://www.hackread.com/android-users-malware-apps-google-play-store/
Malware.Persirai: Persirai is a malware that compromises an IP camera. One interesting feature of Persirai is that when it compromises an IP camera, that camera will start attacking others by exploiting three known vulnerabilities: 1. login.cgi - allows attackers to bypass authentication and get the admin password 2. set_ftp.cgi - when the attacker knows the admin password, he can use this for command injections and malware deployment and 3. CVE-2014-8361, this vulnerability allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted New Internal Client request. Through these vulnerabilities, the attacker will be able to get users’ passwords, and can deploy command injections regardless of password strength.  Active threat, included in KB https://www.trendmicro.com/vinfo/us/security/news/internet-of-things/routex- malware-found-exploiting-remote-access-vulnerability-in-netgear-routers
Malware.Ermac: ERMAC is a code-wise inheritor of the well-known malware Cerberus. It uses almost identical data structures when communicating with the C2. It however uses different obfuscation techniques and a new method of string encryption - Blowfish encryption algorithm. ERMAC gets masqueraded as a legit app such as antivirus, banking, and media player apps. It is a threat for mobile banking users and financial institutions all over the world. ERMAC uses AES-128-CBC encryption scheme in communication with the C2. Threat actor DukeEugene has been seen using this malware in their campaigns.  300,000 Android users impacted by malware apps on Play Store. https://www.hackread.com/android-users-malware-apps-google-play-store/
Malware.Brunhilda: Brunhilda is a DaaS (Dropper as a Service) known for dropping android trojan. Each malicious application in the Google Play Store, when downloaded, communicates with a proxy URL/IP to notify the Brunhilda distribution framework by sending a registration request. The request contains information about the victim’s phone such as device model, Android version, package name, and default language. Brunhilda sends a registration request to its C2 using the gRPC protocol. Upon successful registration, and after communicating more detailed information about the device, the dropper is instructed by the C2 to download and install the payload package.  300,000 Android users impacted by malware apps on Play Store. https://www.hackread.com/android-users-malware-apps-google-play-store/
Malware.GymDrop: This dropper, Gymdrop is an example of how cybercriminals try to convince victims and detection systems that their app is legitimate. The developer website also serves as C2 for Gymdrop. The dropper tries to convince victims to install a fake update or the payload is posed as a new package of workout exercises in conformity with the app. After the user clicks “OK”, the dropper requests the permissions needed. Shortly after the dropper gets its configuration from the C2. The configuration file contains the link to download the payload. This dropper also does not request Accessibility Service privileges, it just requests permission to install packages. When installed, the payload is launched. This dropper is used to distribute Alien banking trojan.  300,000 Android users impacted by malware apps on Play Store. https://www.hackread.com/android-users-malware-apps-google-play-store/
Malware.EwDoor: EwDoor is a backdoor that targets AT&T network devices. Propagating through a flaw in EdgeMarc devices, EwDoor supports a variety of features, including the ability to self-update, download files, obtain a reverse shell on the compromised machine, and execute arbitrary payloads. The vulnerability in question is CVE-2017-6079 (CVSS score: 9.8), a command injection flaw affecting the session border controllers that could be weaponized to execute malicious commands. EwDoor, besides gathering information about the infected system, also establishes communications with a remote command-and-control (C2) server, either directly or indirectly using BitTorrent Trackers to fetch the C2 server IP address, to await further commands issued by the attackers.  EwDoor Botnet Is Attacking AT&T Customers https://blog.netlab.360.com/warning-ewdoor-botnet-is-attacking-att-customers
Malware.NginRAT: NginRAT is a remote access Trojan, made to attack Linux devices. It hides on Nginx servers bypassing security solutions. Like CronRAT, NginRAT also works as a “server- side Magecart,” it injects itself into an Nginx process. NginRAT essentially hijacks a host Nginx application to masquerade its presence. To do that, NginRAT modifies the core functionality of the Linux host system. When the legitimate Nginx web server uses such functionality (eg dlopen), NginRAT injects itself. The result is a remote access trojan that is embedded in the Nginx process.  NginRAT – A stealth malware targets e-store hiding on Nginx servers https://securityaffairs.co/wordpress/125216/malware/nginrat-magecart-attack. html
Malware.Ferocious Dropper: The ferocious dropper is a malware that drops PowerShell script, LitePower. It does so by leveraging a living-off-the-land (LotL) technique called COM hijacking to achieve persistence and triggers the execution of a PowerShell script dubbed LitePower.  Used by Wirte TA group in their campaigns to deliver LitePower Malware https://securelist.com/wirtes-campaign-in-the-middle-east-living-off-the-land- since-at-least-2019/105044/
Malware.Gustuff: Gustuff is an Android Banking Trojan, successor of AndyBot equipped with web fakes designed to potentially target users of mobile Android apps of top international banks and crypto services. The price for leasing the Gustuff Bot is known to be $800 per month. Gustuff infects Android smartphones through SMS with links to malicious Android Package (APK) file, the package file format used by the Android operating system for distribution and installation of applications. When an Android device is infected with Gustuff, at the server’s command Trojan spreads further through the infected device’s contact list or the server database. Gustuff’s features are aimed at mass infections and maximum profit for its operators. It has a unique feature - ATS (Automatic Transfer Systems), that autofills fields in legitimate mobile banking apps, cryptocurrency wallets, and other apps, which both speeds and scales up thefts.  300,000 Android users impacted by malware apps on Play Store. https://www.threatfabric.com/blogs/deceive-the-heavens-to-cross-the-sea.html
Malware.PoorAim: POORAIM malware is designed with basic backdoor functionality and leverages AOL Instant Messenger for command and control communications. POORAIM includes the following capabilities: System information enumeration, File browsing, manipulation and exfiltration, Process enumeration, Screen capture, File execution, Exfiltration of browser favorites, and battery status. Exfiltrated data is sent via files over AIM. POORAIM has been involved in campaigns against South Korean media organizations and sites relating to North Korean refugees and defectors since early 2014. Compromised sites have acted as watering holes to deliver newer variants of POORAIM.  Malware used by APT37 https://www2.fireeye.com/rs/848-DID-242/images/rpt_APT37.pdf
Malware.GELCAPSULE: GELCAPSULE is a downloader traditionally dropped or downloaded by an exploit document. GELCAPSULE has been observed downloading SLOWDRIFT malware to victim systems. It is known to be used by APT 37 in their attack campaigns.  Malware Used by APT37 https://www2.fireeye.com/rs/848-DID-242/images/rpt_APT37.pdf
Malware.RICECURRY: RICECURRY is a Javascript-based profiler used to fingerprint a victim’s web browser and deliver malicious code in return. Browser, operating system, and Adobe Flash version are detected by RICECURRY, which may be a modified version of PluginDetect (PluginDetect is a Javascript library that detects browser plugins). The Javascript- based malware was found to be used by threat actor APT37.  Malware Used by APT37 https://www2.fireeye.com/rs/848-DID-242/images/rpt_APT37.pdf
Malware.CeeLoader: CeeLoader is a custom downloader, written in C, and supports the execution of shellcode payloads directly in memory. The malware is heavily obfuscated, and mixes calls to the Windows API with large blocks of junk code to evade detection by security software. Ceeloader communicates via HTTP, while the C2 response is decrypted using AES-256 in CBC mode. The custom Ceeloader downloader is installed and executed by a Cobalt Strike beacon as needed and does not include persistence to allow it to automatically run when Window is started. It is developed and used by APT29 in their attack campaigns.  Suspected Russian Activity Targeting Government and Business Entities Around the Globe https://www.mandiant.com/resources/russian-targeting-gov-business
Malware.SOUNDWAVE: SOUNDWAVE is a windows based audio capturing utility. Via command line, it accepts the -l switch (for listen probably), captures microphone input for 100 minutes, writing the data out to a log file in this format: C:\Temp\HncDownload\YYYYMMDDHHMMSS. log. This malware was found to be associated with APT37 in their campaigns.  | Details on SOUNDWAVE Malware Used by APT37 https://www2.fireeye.com/rs/848-DID-242/images/rpt_APT37.pdf
Malware.BRATA: BRATA is an Android remote access trojan (RAT) that was first potted in Brazil and then Italy, with threat actors calling victims of SMS attacks to steal their online banking credentials. It can pass undetected by the vast majority of AV scanners. The attack begins with an unsolicited SMS text linking a malicious website. This text claims to be a message from the bank urging the recipient to download an anti-spam app. The link leads to a page from where the victim downloads the BRATA malware themselves or takes them to a phishing page to enter their banking credentials. During that step, the threat actors call the victim on the phone and pretend to be an employee of the bank, offering help with installing the app. The actors abuse these permissions to access the victim’s bank account, retrieve the 2FA code, and eventually perform fraudulent transactions.  Fake support agents call victims to install Android banking malware https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/fake-support-agents-call- victims-to-install-android-banking-malware/
Malware.Magnat: Magnat is a backdoor or backdoor installer that configures the system for stealthy RDP access, adds a new user, and sets a scheduled task to periodically ping the C2 and, when instructed, creates an outbound ssh tunnel forwarding the RDP service. MagnatBackdoor was being distributed through early 2020. MagnatBackdoor is an AutoIt-based installer that prepares a system for remote Microsoft Remote Desktop access and forwards the RDP service port on an outbound SSH tunnel. As a result of this installer’s actions, there is a way for the attacker to access the system remotely via RDP, which is why it’s called a backdoor.  Cyber criminals are using fake advertising to distribute malware https://www.techspot.com/news/92503-cyber-criminals-using-fake-advertising- distribute-malware.html
Malware.ZUMKONG: ZUMKONG is a credential stealer capable of harvesting usernames and passwords stored by Internet Explorer and Chrome browsers. Stolen credentials are emailed to the attacker via HTTP POST requests. The malware is known to be used by APT37 in their attack campaigns.  Malware Used by APT37 https://www2.fireeye.com/rs/848-DID-242/images/rpt_APT37.pdf
Malware.Tor2Mine: Tor2Mine is a crypto-miner that steals XMR cryptocurrency. It uses a PowerShell script that attempts to disable malware protection, execute a miner payload, and harvest Windows credentials. Using those credentials, Tor2Mine can spread itself and will continue to re-infect other systems on the compromised network if not completely eradicated and malware protection is not present. On systems where it manages to gain administrative credentials, Tor2Mine installs executables as a service and then searches for other machines on the network that it can remotely execute installation scripts on to spread further. On systems where it does not gain administrative privileges, Tor2Mine can execute filelessly by way of commands run as scheduled tasks.  Big enterprises warned of a new Monero malware targeting networks https://www.crypto-news-flash.com/big-enterprises-warned-of-a-new-monero- malware-targeting-networks/
Malware.RUHAPPY: RUHAPPY is a destructive wiper tool seen on systems targeted by DOGCALL. It attempts to overwrite the MBR (Memory Boot Record), causing the system not to boot. When victims’ systems attempt to boot, the string “Are you Happy?” is displayed. The malware is believed to be tied to the developers of DOGCALL and HAPPYWORK based on similar PDB (Program database) paths in all three.  Malware Used by APT37 https://www2.fireeye.com/rs/848-DID-242/images/rpt_APT37.pdf
Malware.CypherIT: The CypherIT Autoit is not a threatening application, but it is likely to be used for nefarious purposes since this program is meant to obfuscate the contents of an executable file, therefore making it difficult for anti-virus products to detect any harmful traits. The CypherIT Autoit application is known as ‘packer’ or ‘crypter’ in the cybercrime field, and it is one of the many tools that cybercriminals use to make their harmful applications capable of evading anti-virus products and other security measures. CypherIT Autoit has been used in combination with the AZORult infostealer, a threat capable of collecting login credentials, payment details and other sensitive data silently.
Malware.TigerRAT: The TigerRAT payload capability includes the ability to manipulate files, execute remote commands, log keystrokes, and remotely view and control the screen. TigerRAT may be blocked by VMware Carbon Black. The malware is written in C++ and makes use of only a handful of classes.  TigerRAT – Advanced Adversaries on the Prowl https://blogs.vmware.com/security/2021/12/tigerrat-advanced-adversaries-on- the-prowl.html
Malware.JSPRAT: JSPRAT allows the actor to achieve local command execution, upload/download files, and proxy network traffic for additional pivoting during later stages of the intrusion. The malware has been seen used by threat actor FIN13 in their attack campaigns.  Malware used by new threat actor, FIN13 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/fin13-cybercriminal-mexico
Malware.BLUEAGAVE: BLUEAGAVE is a PowerShell passive backdoor that utilizes the HttpListener .NET class to establish a local HTTP server on high ephemeral ports (65510-65512). The backdoor listens for incoming HTTP requests to the root URI / on the established port, parses the HTTP request, and executes the URL encoded data stored within the ‘kmd’ variable of the request via the Windows Command Prompt (cmd.exe). The output of this command is then sent back to the operator in the body of the HTTP response. The malware was seen being used by FIN13.
Malware.LATCHKEY: LATCHKEY, a custom dropper is a PowerShell to EXE (PS2EXE) compiled dropper that base64 decodes and executes the PowerSploit function, Out-Minidump which generates a minidump for the LSASS (Local Security Authority Subsystem Service) system process to disk.  Malware used by new threat actor, FIN13 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/fin13-cybercriminal-mexico
Malware.PORTHOLE: PORTHOLE is a Java-based port scanner, to conduct network research. PORTHOLE may attempt multiple socket connections to many IPs and ports and, as it is multi- threaded, can execute this operation rapidly with potentially multiple overlapping connections. The malware accepts as its first argument either an IP address with wildcards in the address or a filename. The second argument is the starting port range to scan for each IP, and the third is the ending port range. It was detected being used by FIN13 in their attack campaigns.  Malware used by new threat actor, FIN13 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/fin13-cybercriminal-mexico
Malware.CLOSEWATCH: CLOSEWATCH is a JSP web shell that communicates with a listener on localhost over a specified port, writes arbitrary files to the victim operating system, executes arbitrary commands on the victim host, disables proxying and issues customizable HTTP GET requests to a range of remote hosts. If the proper HTTP URL parameters are specified, CLOSEWATCH can create a socket connection to localhost on port
Malware.SPINOFF: SPINOFF is a JSP Webshell that can execute arbitrary SQL queries on specified databases and download the results to a file. The malware was found to be used in attack campaigns ran by FIN13.  Can you tell me about SPINOFF https://www.mandiant.com/resources/fin13-cybercriminal-mexico
Malware.DRAWSTRING: DRAWSTRING is a downloader that has some internal recon functionality. While primarily providing threat actors the ability to download and execute arbitrary files, DRAWSTRING also executes systeminfo.exe and upload that information to a command and control (C2) server. On startup the malware creates persistence through three possible methods: a Service, a .lnk file, or an update to the Software\ Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run registry key. The malware checks for the numerous anti-virus processes and varies the persistence method if one is found.  Malware used by new threat actor, FIN13 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/fin13-cybercriminal-mexico
Malware.BUSTEDPIPE: BUSTEDPIPE is a custom JSP web shell tunneler to facilitate lateral movement via web requests. The malware was seen being used by FIN13 in their attack campaigns.  Malware used by new threat actor, FIN13 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/fin13-cybercriminal-mexico
Malware.NIGHTJAR: NIGHTJAR is a Java uploader observed during multiple investigations that appears to be based on code implementing TCP by transferring a file between the client and server by using the localhost address where any address can be placed even remote addresses are supported with certain file permissions. NIGHTJAR listens on a designated socket, provided at runtime on the command line, to download a file and save it to disk. This malware does not contain a persistence mechanism and has been observed in the C:\Windows\Temp or C:\inetpub\wwwroot directory. FIN13 uses this malware in its malicious campaigns.  Malware used by new threat actor, FIN13 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/fin13-cybercriminal-mexico
Malware.SIXPACK: SIXPACK is an ASPX web shell written in C# that functions as a tunneler. SIXPACK accepts HTTP form data that contains a remote host and TCP port to connect to, a timeout value, and Base64-encoded data to send after connecting to the specified host. Response data is read by SIXPACK and returned to the original client. The malware is used by threat actor FIN13.  Malware used by new threat actor, FIN13 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/fin13-cybercriminal-mexico
Malware.SWEARJAR: SWEARJAR is a Java-based cross-platform backdoor that can execute shell commands. FIN13 uses this malware in its financially motivated attack campaigns.  Malware used by new threat actor, FIN13 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/fin13-cybercriminal-mexico
Malware.MAILSLOT: This backdoor called MAILSLOT, communicates over SMTP/POP over SSL, sending and receiving emails to and from a configured attacker-controlled email account for its command and control. MAILSLOT makes FIN13 a rare case of a threat actor who has used email communications for C2.  Malware used by new threat actor, FIN13 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/fin13-cybercriminal-mexico
Malware.HOTLANE: HOTLANE is a custom utility, which is a tunneler written in C/C++ that can operate in client or server mode and communicates with a custom binary protocol over TCP. FIN13 uses this malware in its financially motivated campaigns.  Malware used by new threat actor, FIN13 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/fin13-cybercriminal-mexico
Malware.GoBot2: GoBot2, has many different variants. That is because it is available as an open-source code, and anyone can use it to build their own version of the Trojan. The attackers can choose from features that are already available and then build upon that. Without a doubt, how this malware spreads depends on the attackers behind it.
Malware.TinyShell: TinyShell is a python command shell used to control and execute commands through HTTP requests to a webshell. TinyShell acts as the interface to the remote webshells. It is an open-source malware for pen-testing.  Malware used by new threat actor, FIN13 https://www.mandiant.com/resources/fin13-cybercriminal-mexico
Malware.Muhstik: Muhstik is a botnet that leverages known web application exploits to compromise IoT devices, such as routers, to mine cryptocurrency. It leverages IRC servers for its command-and-control (C2) activities. Some of the vulnerabilities exploited by Muhstik include Oracle WebLogic Server bugs (CVE-2019-2725 and CVE-2017-10271) and Drupal RCE flaw (CVE-2018-7600). The botnet mainly funds itself by mining cryptocurrency using open source tools like XMRig and cgminer.  Chinese-linked Muhstik botnet targets Oracle WebLogic, Drupal https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/chinese-linked-muhstik- botnet-targets-oracle-weblogic-drupal/
Malware.Owowa: Owowa is a C#-developed .NET v4.0 assembly that is intended to be loaded as a module within an IIS web server that also exposes Exchange’s Outlook Web Access (OWA). When loaded this way, Owowa will steal credentials that are entered by any user in the OWA login page, and will allow a remote operator to run commands on the underlying server.  Owowa: the add-on that turns your OWA into a credential stealer and remote access panel https://securelist.com/owowa-credential-stealer-and-remote-access/105219/
Malware.Tengyun: This malware is used by Tengyun Snake Organisation for attacks against Pakistan and Bangladesh to infiltrate, spread malicious programs to the target device, secretly control the target device, and continue to steal sensitive files.  OBSERVED APT-C-61 THREAT ACTOR’S MALICIOUS ACTIVITIES TARGETING BANGLADESH https://www.cirt.gov.bd/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/CYBER-ESPIONAGE- ACTIVITIES_-APT-C-61.pdf
Malware.PseudoManuscrypt: The PseudoManuscrypt loader makes its way onto user systems via a MaaS platform that distributes malware in pirated software installer archives. The main PseudoManuscrypt module has extensive and varied spying functionality. It includes stealing VPN connection data, logging keypresses, capturing screenshots and videos of the screen, recording sound with the microphone, stealing clipboard data and operating system event log data (which also makes stealing RDP authentication data possible), and much more. Essentially, the functionality of PseudoManuscrypt provides the attackers with virtually full control of the infected system. Targets of PseudoManuscrypt attacks include a significant number of industrial and government organizations, including enterprises in the military-industrial complex and research laboratories.  PseudoManuscrypt: a mass-scale spyware attack campaign https://securelist.com/pseudomanuscrypt-a-mass-scale-spyware-attack- campaign/105286/
Malware.Kelihos Backdoor: The Kelihos backdoor is able to rope the affected system into the Kelihos botnet, which is typically used to send out spam email messages. Kelihos malware is often dropped and installed as the payload of other malware, such as trojan- downloaders. Some variants are also distributed via links to malicious websites that are circulated through the Facebook social network. Once the malware has been installed on a system, it typically tries to contact a remote server and download its other components, including a backdoor that gives remote attackers further control over the affected system. The backdoor also connects the system to a botnet under the attacker’s control. Once included in the botnet, the affected system may be instructed to download other malware, or be used to send spam email messages to other victims. It may also be directed to perform other malicious actions, such as stealing Bitcoins.  Active threat, added in KB https://www.f-secure.com/v-descs/backdoor_w32_kelihos.shtml
Malware.Kelihos Botnet: The botnet (referred to as the Kelihos or Hlux botnet) is built on a peer-to-peer or P2P infrastructure, so commands are relayed through other similarly infected machines from the attacker’s command and control server (a structure that makes this kind of botnet much harder to detect and shut down).  Active threat, added in KB https://www.f-secure.com/v-descs/backdoor_w32_kelihos.shtml
Malware.DarkWatchman: DarkWatchman has been observed being distributed by email and represents an evolution in fileless malware techniques, as it uses the registry for nearly all temporary and permanent storage and therefore never writes anything to disk, allowing it to operate beneath or around the detection threshold of most security tools. It is a malicious javascript-based Remote Access Trojan (RAT) that uses a robust Domain Generation Algorithm (DGA) to identify its Command and Control (C2) infrastructure and that utilizes novel methods for fileless persistence, on-system activity, and dynamic run-time capabilities like self-updating and recompilation.  DarkWatchman: A new evolution in fileless techniques. https://www.prevailion.com/darkwatchman-new-fileness-techniques/
Malware.Slub: The SLUB backdoor is a custom one written in the C++ programming language, statically linking curl library to perform multiple HTTP requests. Other statically-linked libraries are boost (for extracting commands from gist snippets) and JsonCpp (for parsing slack channel communication). The malware also embeds two authorization tokens to communicate with the Slack API. The slack communication function contains two hardcoded authentication tokens split into a few smaller chunks. Later, the backdoor gets the username and computer name, then creates and uploads the Slack message into a channel. The output of every command is sent to a private Slack channel, while every command itself is sent to a different private Slack channel as an attachment with the text “*computername:username*”.  An old threat, added in the KB https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/19/c/new-slub-backdoor-uses- github-communicates-via-slack.html
Malware.Aclip: Aclip is a backdoor, written in PowerShell scripting language. In order to receive commands and send data, the backdoor uses a legitimate functionality in the Slack messaging Application Program Interface (API), which allows apps and services to be developed that can be integrated with the messaging platform. The attackers can create a workspace and channels where they could receive system information, including requested files and screenshots, post commands to the backdoor and receive commands. Aclip bears high-level similarities with other tools developed by ITG17 and is said to be associated with the mentioned threat actor.  NATION-STATE ATTACKERS TARGETED AIRLINE WITH NEW BACKDOOR https://duo.com/decipher/state-sponsored-attackers-targeted-airline-with-new- backdoor

Threat Actors.SilverFish: SilverFish group, was found to have carried out an extremely sophisticated cyber- attack on at least 4720 targets, including but not limited to governmental institutions, global IT providers, the aviation industry, and defense companies. It is detected to have multiple relations with the notorious SolarWinds incident of the past and the globally recognized EvilCorp group. While the United States is by far the most frequently targeted region, with 2465 attacks recorded, it is followed by European states with 1645 victims originating from no less than 6 different member states. The main goal of this APT group is most likely to perform reconnaissance and exfiltrate data from target machines in a covert manner.  Active threat actor, added in the knowledge base. https://www.prodaft.com/m/reports/SilverFish_TLPWHITE_v2.pdf
Threat Actors.Canthroid: Canthroid is a financially motivated threat actor group that focuses on organizations in the financial sector but have also targeted companies in the manufacturing, IT services, consultancy, and engineering sectors. It is known to be affiliated to TheifLock Ransomware and targets victims in the US. The group is said to be associated with Yanluowang Ransomware actors due to higly similar TTPs.
Threat Actors.SideCopy: The SideCopy APT is a Pakistani threat actor that has been operating since at least 2019, mainly targeting South Asian countries and more specifically India and Afghanistan. Its name comes from its infection chain that tries to mimic that of the SideWinder APT. It has been reported that this actor has similarities with Transparent Tribe (APT36) and possibly is a subdivision of this actor. The lures used by SideCopy APT are usually archived files that have embedded one of these files: Lnk, Microsoft Publisher, or Trojanized Applications. SideCopy APT has mainly targeted defense and armed forces personnel in the Indian subcontinent but there are not many reports about how successful these attacks were and what data was exfiltrated.  | What do you know about Threat Actor SideCopy? SideCopy APT: Connecting lures to victims, payloads to infrastructure https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2021/12/sidecopy-apt- connecting-lures-to-victims-payloads-to-infrastructure/
Threat Actors.Magnat: Magnat is a threat actor whose motivations appear to be financial gain from selling stolen credentials, fraudulent transactions, and Remote Desktop access to systems. This threat actor has been found using multiple old and new malware in their malware campaign which are: 1) a commodity password stealer. Initially Azorult and currently Redline. Both steal all the credentials they can find on the system. 2) A backdoor, or backdoor installer MagnatBackdoor that configures the system for stealthy RDP access, adds a new user, and sets a scheduled task to periodically ping the C2 and, when instructed, create an outbound ssh tunnel forwarding the RDP service. 3) An installer for a chrome extension; MagnatExtension that packs several features useful for stealing data from the web browser: a form grabber, keylogger, screenshotter, cookie stealer, and arbitrary JavaScript executor, among others.  Magnat campaigns use malvertising to deliver information stealer, backdoor and malicious Chrome extension https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2021/12/magnat-campaigns-use- malvertising-to.html
Threat Actors.Memento Team: Memento is a ransomware group with financial gain as their motive. What differentiates them is that the Memento Team doesn’t encrypt files; instead, it copies files into password-protected archives, using a renamed freeware version of the legitimate file utility WinRAR - and then encrypts the password and deletes the original files. They demand $1 million to restore the files, and threaten data exposure if the victim does not comply. The threat actor is suspected to be from South Korea as malicious commands were executed using the wmiexec remote shell, connecting to a host (now unreachable) in South Korea.  New ransomware actor uses password-protected archives to bypass encryption protection https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2021/11/18/new-ransomware-actor-uses- password-protected-archives-to-bypass-encryption-protection/
Threat Actors.BTCMITM20: BTCMITM20 is a threat actor group that is categorized as a persistent and large-scale activity cluster. It is a financially motivated group that gains financial profit by running thousands of malicious Tor exit nodes in order to replace Bitcoin wallet addresses inside web traffic and hijack user payments. Its target is to collect information on users connecting to the Tor network and attempting to map their routes inside it. The threat actor is active since at least 2020.  A mysterious threat actor is running hundreds of malicious Tor relays https://therecord.media/a-mysterious-threat-actor-is-running-hundreds-of- malicious-tor-relays/
Threat Actors.KAX17: Since at least 2017, KAX17 (categorized as a non-amateur and persistent threat actor) has run thousands of malicious servers in entry, middle, and exit positions of the Tor network in what a security researcher has described as an attempt to deanonymize (a data mining technique) Tor users. Tracked as KAX17, the threat actor ran at its peak more than 900 malicious servers part of the Tor network, which typically tends to hover around a daily total of up to 9,000-10,000. Their role is to encrypt and anonymize user traffic as it enters and leaves the Tor network, creating a giant mesh of proxy servers that bounce connections between each other and provide the much-needed privacy that Tor users come for. This threat actor has constantly added servers with no contact details to the Tor network in industrial quantities, operating servers in the realm of hundreds at any given point. The actor’s servers are typically located in data centers spread all over the world and are typically configured as entry and middle points primarily, although KAX17 also operates a small number of exit points.  A mysterious threat actor is running hundreds of malicious Tor relays https://therecord.media/a-mysterious-threat-actor-is-running-hundreds-of- malicious-tor-relays/
Threat Actors.XE Group: The attacker appears to be of Vietnamese origin. They often use the brand ‘XE Group,’ and a number of ‘xe[word]’ themed domains have been registered and linked to the group. This threat actor intrusions follow an approximate pattern: 1)Compromise of externally facing services via known exploits (e.g., Telerik UI vulnerabilities) 2) Monetization of these compromises through installation of password theft or credit card skimming code for web services related to these servers. Researchers have identified a likely persona on carding forums associated with this activity, which suggests the attacker monetizes stolen credit card data through sales rather than direct use of stolen cards themselves. The persona used for the GitHub and carding account, and several of the domains, have a history going back to 2013, which suggests the attacker may have been attempting similar attacks for up to eight years, with only one significant public mention of their activity. The oldest malware sample relating to XE Group dates back to late 2014.  XE Group – Exposed: 8 Years of Hacking & Card Skimming for Profit https://www.volexity.com/blog/2021/12/07/xe-group-exposed-8-years-of- hacking-card-skimming-for-profit/
Threat Actors.Cuba Ransomware Group: Cuba Ransomware group targets enterprises in the financial, government, healthcare, manufacturing, and information technology sectors while using the Hancitor malware to gain entry to Windows systems. The eye-popping ransom payments were dwarfed by the amount of money the group has demanded from victims, summing up to $74 million (2021). Cuba ransomware actors use MimiKatz malware to steal credentials and then use RDP to log into the compromised network host with a specific user account. Once an RDP connection is complete, the Cuba ransomware actors use the CobaltStrike server to communicate with the compromised user account. The group typically targets companies in the US, South America, and Europe. The attackers operate using a set of PowerShell scripts that enables them to move laterally. The ransom note mentions that the data was exfiltrated before being encrypted.  FBI: Cuba ransomware group hit 49 critical infrastructure organizations https://www.zdnet.com/article/fbi-cuba-ransomware-hit-49-critical- infrastructure-organizations/
Threat Actors.FIN13: In contrast to other financially motivated actors, FIN13 has highly localized targeting. Research data shows FIN13 operates exclusively against organizations based in Mexico and has specifically targeted large organizations in the financial, retail, and hospitality industries. FIN13 thoroughly maps a victim’s network, captures credentials, steals corporate documents, technical documentation, financial databases, and other files that support their objective of financial gain through the fraudulent transfer of funds from the victim organization.  FIN13: A Cybercriminal Threat Actor Focused on Mexico https://www.mandiant.com/resources/fin13-cybercriminal-mexico
Threat Actors.Karakurt: Operating under the self-proclaimed name, “Karakurt” started ramping up attacks late in the third quarter of 2021 and continued into the fourth quarter. The presence of Karakurt was first identified in June 2021 as it registered its apparent dump-site domains, followed by their Twitter handle “karakurtlair” in August 2021. The threat group has claimed to have impacted over 40 victims across multiple industries between September 2021 and November 2021. Of note, Karakurt focuses solely on data exfiltration and subsequent extortion, rather than the more destructive ransomware deployment. The Karakurt group does not appear to focus on a specific industry vertical or size. Of known victims, 95% are based in North America with the remaining 5% in Europe. From researchers’ investigations into the group’s activity, it was determined that it typically uses credential access as the initial vector into victims’ networks and utilizes applications already installed to move laterally and exfiltrate data, if available.  Karakurt rises from its lair https://www.accenture.com/us-en/blogs/cyber-defense/karakurt-threat- mitigation
Threat Actors.Khonsari Ransomware Gang: The threat actor is known for using Khonsari Ransomware for financial gain by exploiting CVE-2021-44228 (Log4Shell) in their attack campaigns.  Novel Khonsari Ransomware Deployed by the Log4Shell Vulnerability https://www.cadosecurity.com/analysis-of-novel-khonsari-ransomware- deployed-by-the-log4shell-vulnerability/
Threat Actors.Snatch Ransomware Group: This ransomware group is known to be using Snatch ransomware in attacks against America, Europe, and Canada. Snatch uses automated brute-force attacks to infiltrate company networks before spreading laterally. In an incident in October 2019, the attackers brute-forced the password to an administrator’s account on a Microsoft Azure server and were able to log in to the server using Remote Desktop (RDP). From there, Snatch spread other executables, designed to give the attackers remote access without having to rely on the compromised Azure server, to 200 machines, or roughly
Threat Actors.Tengyun Snake Organisation: The group uses Tengyun malware to target the military industry, as well as national and research institutions in Pakistan and Bangladesh. The actor is believed to exfiltrate sensitive data to existing C2 or cloud-based servers to avoid detection. The researchers think it likely that the actor is preparing for ransomware attacks, and will possibly target the banking and finance industry in the future. Tengyun Snake Organisation / Tengyun-Snake / APT-C- OBSERVED APT-C-61 THREAT ACTOR’S MALICIOUS ACTIVITIES TARGETING BANGLADESH https://www.cirt.gov.bd/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/CYBER-ESPIONAGE- ACTIVITIES_-APT-C-61.pdf
